name: Klára DOBREV
text: Before we begin the vote, I would like to give the floor to Mr Vincze Lóránt, who wishes to speak under Article 59(4) of the Rules of Procedure on interim measures relating to the deadlines for the collection, control and inspection phases in view of the Covid19 epidemic (2020/0099(COD)) for interinstitutional negotiations and for the matter to be referred back to the Commission.

name: Loránt VINCZE
text: Rapporteur. – I would like to ask the House to agree that after the vote on the regulation laying down temporary measures concerning the time limits for the collection, verification and examination stages provided for in Regulation 788 on the European citizens’ initiative in view of the COVID-19 outbreak, we refer the matter back to the Committee on Constitutional Affairs (AFCO) for interinstitutional negotiations under Rule 59(4).

name: Klára DOBREV
text: The request will be voted on after the final vote on the Commission's proposal. The first round of voting is hereby opened.  The vote will take place from 9 a.m. to 10:15 a.m. The voting method is the same as yesterday. All votes will be roll-call ballots and Members will be able to check their votes and the results of the votes in a document published on the plenary website. Ballot papers may be submitted in writing. Exceptionally, only voting votes of up to 400 words are accepted.  I hereby open the first round of voting. They have until 10.15am to vote. The results of the polls will be announced at 1.30pm. (The sitting was suspended at 9.04 a.m.)

name: Klára DOBREV
text: The next item is the Commission's statement on large-scale land acquisition and deforestation in Amazonia (2020/2689(RSP)). I would like to inform Members that there will be no catch-the-eye procedure or blue card issues at the end of this debate.

name: Virginijus Sinkevičius
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, the Amazon is a rainforest without equal. It plays a unique role for the health of our planet, our diversity and our climate. It is also essential for the indigenous people that call it home and depend on it for their livelihoods and their traditional culture.  The challenges that affect the Amazon Basin are complex, multi-faceted and require close regional cooperation among the countries that share it. The environmental dimension of these challenges is closely interconnected with fundamental socio-economic factors, as well as issues such as widespread poverty, corruption, human rights abuses, stability and security.  Territories of indigenous people and local communities in the Amazon overlap to a very large degree with the world’s best-preserved biodiversity and ecosystems. The indigenous people and local communities have therefore to be part of the solution. Tackling deforestation in the Amazon is essential not only to fight global biodiversity loss and climate change, but also to achieve sustainable development and poverty eradication. In line with the ambitions set out in the European Green Deal and the new EU biodiversity strategy for 2030, the EU is fully committed to tackling deforestation. We are determined to take a leading role internationally and to use diplomacy, trade policy and development cooperation tools. At the global level, the EU will push for an ambitious post-2020 global biodiversity framework to ensure that by 2050 all of the world’s ecosystems, including forests, are restored, resilient and adequately protected.  The global framework should include specific targets for halting the loss of primary forests and for preserving ecosystems’ health, in line with the proposals in the EU biodiversity strategy. We will continue to support action against deforestation and forest degradation as a part of the implementation of the Paris Agreement, including through continued commitment to raise the ambition of forest competence, of nationally determined contributions and continued support to the international initiative on reducing emissions for deforestation and forest degradation.  With regard to EU policies, the Commission is working on a series of actions to fight deforestation as a part of the follow-up to our communication on stepping-up EU action to protect and restore the world’s forests adopted in July 2019. As part of the follow up to last year’s communication, the Commission will present in 2021 a legislative proposal and other measures to avoid or minimise the placing of products associated with deforestation on the EU market and to promote forest-friendly imports and value chains. We are currently conducting the related impact assessment.  Instruments could include voluntary commitment of the industry, mandatory labelling, due diligence, certification schemes, approaches similar to the EU system against illegal fishing, bilateral agreements or other measures.  We very much welcome the European Parliament’s engagement on deforestation and look forward to Ms Burkhardt’s draft legislative initiative report, which once adopted, we will evaluate carefully. To tackle the issue of deforestation, we also need to engage more with the private sector, especially with the EU, to get stronger commitments from their side on sustainable sourcing.  As announced in the biodiversity strategy, the Commission will also put forward a new initiative in 2021 on sustainable corporate governance. This initiative will address human rights, environmental duty of care and due diligence across sectors. Other action taken by the Commission includes the creation of a multi-stakeholder platform on deforestation, which will meet for the first time in October and of an EU observatory that will use the earth observation and trade data to facilitate information on global deforestation.  The EU is determined to work in partnership with, and support efforts by partner countries in the Amazon to tackle deforestation. Human rights, including those of indigenous people, and local communities in the Amazon, as well as environmental protection are at the core of the values underpinning the EU relations with third countries, including the countries of the Amazon basin.  Therefore, these issues are systematically raised within our established mechanisms for political dialogue and cooperation. Our dialogue is not limited to central government. We are also actively engaging with a broad range of stakeholders including sub-national local governance, judiciary authorities, civil society and progressive business associations. Our dialogue is key to success.  Free trade agreements with countries in the region are another way to engage and promote cooperation on international commitments on climate and the environment in particular, in the context of their trade and sustainable development chapters.  The EU is addressing the root causes of deforestation through our significant development assistance to forests, land use, sustainable livelihoods and indigenous people in the Amazon basin, with a total of ongoing projects amounting to EUR 166 million.  Protecting biodiversity and fighting deforestation requires protected areas and good governance. It also goes hand in hand with improving the livelihoods of local populations and respecting the rights of indigenous people. This integrated sustainable development approach is at the centre of our development cooperation policy. The Commission supports the implementation of the ILO Convention 169 on the indigenous and tribal people as well as the implementation of the UN voluntary guidelines on governance of tenure of land and forests. Finally, our human rights instruments have been mobilised on rights of indigenous people and of environmental defenders, unfortunately too often at stake in the Amazon region. I look forward to working closely with you on this important issue.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, and thank you Commissioner for your commitment to the future, but of course we have had this debate here in the Chamber before. Last summer we all watched as the Amazon burned, and despite our lofty words and our concerns, nothing has changed. And that’s why we’re back here today talking about land—grabbing and deforestation. We cannot take our eyes off this subject.  We’re very alarmed about the continued loss of forests in the Amazon to commercial agriculture, logging and mining. We are alarmed at the proposed law to legalise land—grabbing by the Brazilian government, which would further incentivise taking of public lands into private ownership and the destruction of more forest area. And I think we need to get into our heads the scale of this. You’re talking about an area of over 60 million hectares.  We are working on a new climate law in this house with commitments on climate neutrality by 2050. We’re leading as we should. We’re ambitious and we want to lead the way. But we can’t do it on our own. COVID-19 will see the world’s emissions of carbon dioxide fall by 7% this year. Yet in Brazil, we will see them rise by 10% because, and mainly due to, deforestation.  Ratification of the EU Mercosur trade deal is still on the agenda. We continue to be concerned about the opening up of European markets to more beef and soya and its consequences for deforestation. Despite being told by the Commission that the deal will encourage Brazil and the Mercosur bloc to meet climate obligations, we remain sceptical. But people in glass houses should not throw too many stones. We are part of the problem. Our own meat production demands protein for animal feed and it comes from Brazil and other places. Yet we have restricted the ability of our own grain growers to supply the market because of the rules we have imposed but have no control over what comes into Europe.  My last remark is as follows: I hope that the EU Farm to Fork strategy, the biodiversity strategy, and more importantly the review of EU trade policy just launched, will look closely at the complexity of our supply chains and the absolute contradiction between our agriculture, environment, trade and climate policy.  We’ve got to do that now Commissioner.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I welcome the Commissioner’s introduction and I have to say that I do not doubt the intentions of this Commission to tackle climate and deforestation together. But, if we want to achieve our goals, and we know what our goals are, then the Amazon is key in that fight. It’s the largest carbon sink on the planet, and the dramatic thing is, it is changing. If we do not act decisively, the Amazon could be a net carbon emitter by 2030. Can you imagine what the effect of that could be? So, the situation is really serious, and we have to act decisively on it and ensure that it is not hopeless. Last year, as mentioned, we already discussed the wildfires in the Amazon. Well, let me tell you that, since then, the situation is getting worse every month and the fire season hasn’t even started. As mentioned earlier, 80% of deforestation is linked to agriculture and to consumption in Europe, so we do have a task ahead.  We have an extremely vigilant task: the Bolsonaro Government is using the COVID—19 crisis to push through further deregulation on environmental policy. We already know that the government blocked 30% of the National Environment Agency’s budget for fire prevention. We also know that the Bolsonaro administration has fired most of the directors of the Environmental Institute controlling illegal logging. We know that they fired the head of Brazil’s space agency, which collects data on forests. And today, using the COVID crisis to recognise land grabbing is simply unacceptable. Exactly one year ago, the European Commission signed an agreement with the Mercosur countries on free trade with the inclusion of a so—called binding sustainable chapter. And, as you mentioned, the Commission always argues that that chapter is our safeguard for the preservation of the Amazon. Can we still believe that? That a year after the signing off, the situation is getting worse and worse. So this Parliament needs to ask for real safeguards on the preservation of the Amazon and that will be key in the discussion on the free trade agreement. Let me be clear: no free trade without good climate action. If the world wants to be a partner in trade with us, it needs to be a partner in climate action. And that is for us, the S&D, key for the discussions in the future and the policy of the future, let me be extremely clear on that.

name: Jordi CAÑAS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, the Amazon is under threat. Land grabbing, logging and burning of forest to develop livestock or agricultural activities, illegal obtaining of property titles, along with mining, are responsible for their increasing deforestation and degradation. But in the face of this, what is the best strategy to reverse this situation that threatens climate, biodiversity, but also the sustainable development of Amazonian countries and the right of their citizens to enjoy a dignified life? With permanent reproaches and rebukes tinged with neocolonial paternalism, or, on the contrary, implementing a strategy designed with respect, resources, commitment, cooperation and agreements? Because, ladies and gentlemen, for our climate strategy to have a real global impact, we need partners to join it, and we can only do that on the basis of binding agreements. A vigilant attitude from this Parliament is needed on the political actions of those governments in the region that are going in the wrong direction, but we must also recognise the efforts of the Amazonian countries, which have signed the Paris Agreement, the Leticia Pact or the Escazu Agreement and which have developed national initiatives to combat this situation between tremendous economic and social difficulties. We must also support civil society, indigenous peoples, environmental advocates, i.e. countries. Because countries aren't just their governments. They, like us, pass, but problems continue, and only with real advocacy tools can we contribute to our shared goal. And the most powerful instrument we have is trade and partnership agreements. These are key to collaborating with our partners in climate strategy, such as the Agreement on European Union and Mercosur, an agreement that incorporates a specific chapter dedicated to sustainable development and environmental protection, and which reflects compliance with the Paris Agreement as a binding element. Dear ladies and gentlemen, it will not be with ideological demagoguery that we will put out fires or curb illegal mining, or deforestation, or land grabbing, but with respect, resources, cooperation and agreements.

name: Aurelia BEIGNEUX
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Madam President, indeed, deforestation in the Amazon continues to break records, causing legitimate emotion even on our benches. Tropical forests are the first to be affected by deforestation, both anthropogenic and natural. While your Commission is debating this subject, we see a decline in agrarian land in Europe. In France, they now account for only 54% of the territory, while artificial soils are increasing, now accounting for 10% of the metropolis. Who's to blame? To you and to your agricultural model. If you should criticize the Brazilian government's assessment of the situation, it cannot distract you from your own responsibilities. How can you be outraged by the practices of third countries when European imports promote imported deforestation? Europe is the leading continent in terms of imported deforestation. The European Union has a direct influence on the importation of soy, palm oil, cocoa and rubber products. As for land grabbing, its causes are clear: agricultural globalization. For the past 20 years, soybeans have been one of the main drivers of deforestation, particularly in the Amazon. Between 70% and 90% of the world's soybean production is used to feed livestock. It is then purchased by the food industry and the retail industry. This intensive model is one of the pillars of your treaties, the latest, the famous and shameful treaty of Mercosur. How can you worry about deforestation in Brazil when you know that the Mercosur Treaty encourages this practice? It's disgraceful! It is for this reason that the Dutch Parliament voted against this Treaty, and I welcome it. As a reminder, the European Union wants to import more than 300,000 tonnes of meat from South America with greatly reduced tariffs. And again, your European vision harms both producers and the environment. You are therefore fatally a link in the chain of deforestation, it must be acknowledged. How can you be moved by this situation when many of you are slavishly signing the free trade treaties that cause this deforestation? Let us get out of the many free trade treaties that the European Union has ratified, defend another model geared towards localism, stop importing products of daily life cheaper than the product of the farm next door, stop this excessive liberalisation and return to a truly ethical model.

name: Anna CAVAZZINI
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, first of all, I want to express my solidarity with the people in the Amazon region and especially in Brazil suffering from the outbreak of COVID—19 and losing family members and friends. In this situation, what can be more shocking than hearing a minister calling to get rid of environmental protection while people are distracted by COVID—19? This is what Brazilian Environment Minister, Ricardo Salles, was caught saying on video.  Deforestation in the Amazon keeps increasing and this is a direct consequence of government decisions. Control agencies dismantled, penalty payments for illegal logging stopped and, if this were not enough, the Bolsonaro administration is supporting a law which would legalise land grabbing in the Amazon. This law could be passed by Congress at any moment. I support everyone on the ground fighting these destructive policies and call on my colleagues in the Brazilian Congress to stop this course of action, especially the law on land grabbing. But, of course, we in Europe also have a role to play. Supermarkets in the UK threatened to boycott agricultural products from Brazil if the land grabbing law is passed. In the space of a week, 350 000 people in Germany have signed a petition to ask German supermarkets to do the same and we urgently need deforestation—free supply chains and to end our dependency on the soil.  Let’s face it, I think the Mercosur agreement is dead. Resistance was big before, but now in this line that leads Brazilian environmental policy, I don’t see any chance for that deal.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: , on behalf of the ECR Group. – Dear Colleagues, it is hard to imagine a worse time for this debate. The European continent is shaken by protests, millions of Europeans have lost their jobs, vandals are looting shops, destroying and rewriting European history, and at this point the European Parliament is debating the amazon forests.  Dear colleagues, a brief geographical reminder – the Amazon River does not pass through any Member State where your constituents live and the people who support this institution with their taxes. It is difficult to find a more accurate unit-measure of unsuitability and worthlessness. A stranger would be just a debate about the lack of water on Mars, but I dare not suggest it to you, lest I see it on the next agenda.  Moreover, this chamber talks about ecology and cleanliness of the air when it votes and will vote for thousands of trucks to drive empty across Europe and pollute the air of Europeans. What kind of fat-ass, what a binge. This chamber may decide to keep the European air clean, but under pressure from the EPP, the S&D, the RENEW, because of the party-powered mothers voting - narrowing their ears and voting - for it to be dirty air, and now they are sitting down to teach other countries on other continents how to keep their air. Very strange, dear. If this house votes on air pollution, it should be silent on the Amazon and the like. And one more thing, dear colleagues. Again, we heard even here in the debris, in the jungles of the Amazon, again we heard about colonialism, paternalism, the privilege of white Europeans, that we should apologize for having historical guilt. Dear colleagues, if you think that by apologizing, kneeling, humiliating, self-esteem, self-esteem, you will win more votes, you are deeply wrong. If you think that by justifying riots and barbarism, you will receive support, no, you are wrong. When they're done with the shops, when they're done with the perfumes, they'il come for you, it reminds you of the story. That's how every revolution that raises the red flag, sickle and hammer begins. First he beats, then he grabs the shops, and then he comes for the private property. Look at Bolshevist Russia, look at the history of the occupation of Eastern Europe, including my country. So don't be fooled. You will not get any more votes, you will only get barbarism and obliteration of history. But I don't mind. Anyone who wants to apologize, apologize. Anyone who has doubts or shame about their colonial past, let him apologize. But, dear, please don't waste your time. Don't expect us to apologize for something we're not guilty of.  The Bulgarian does not kneel, the Bulgarian does not humiliate himself, the Bulgarian does not begging for mercy when a robber, enslaved or barbarian comes to the door. When this happens, we Bulgarians stand firmly on our feet and with a strong right hand we defend our home, our homeland, our culture, our family and our homeland.  That's what we do, so I wish you good luck protecting the Amazon forests. It's undeniably an epic, planetary debate. When the next one comes about the need for more Carlsons with fins in the European Union or the need for more windmill struggles on Don Quixote, call me, I'll come, we'll debate and talk about all these things.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, not so long ago the world was outraged by the sight of images of the burning Amazon. Because of the corona crisis, she seems to have faded a bit into the background, but the crisis in the rainforest continues. In fact, she's gotten a lot worse.  The Amazon is of enormous importance for biodiversity and crucial for the climate and for the people and animals that live there. Nevertheless, the Amazon, with the cooperation of the European Union, is rapidly being destroyed and cut down. And with unacceptable human rights violations on the bargain, to fill our fuel tanks, but above all to satisfy our appetite for cheap fodder and cheap meat. Every year, Europe imports around one and a half million tonnes of soya and 140 000 tonnes of beef from Brazil. This will be made even greater if Europe follows through on the Mercosur trade agreement! If we want to save the Amazon and really stop the global biodiversity loss, we have to act accordingly. Commissioner, you cannot succeed with your biodiversity strategy if your colleagues at the same time continue to pursue European trade policy and agricultural policy. If you say yes to a firm climate and biodiversity policy and sustainable food production, are you prepared to say no to destructive trade treaties such as Mercosur, the import of soy for animal feed, spending billions on environmental and climate-damaging subsidies for the livestock industry, including the promotion of meat? Because eating less meat is not only good for the Amazon, but also for the welfare of animals. And speaking of animal welfare, this Parliament has the opportunity to do something about it at this very moment. I call on my colleagues to vote against animal transport before the committee of inquiry is set up, so that the structural and serious abuses in animal transport can finally be thoroughly investigated.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, an investigation by the NGO Animal Equality has shown the link between deforestation in the Amazon and the creation of large livestock farms for slaughter, noting that almost 6 000 square kilometres of rainforest, the equivalent of 60 football fields per hour, have been razed to the ground. Another recent Greenpeace report entitled 'Forests for slaughter' says that EU consumption is linked to 10 % of global deforestation.  European citizens are so unaware of the destruction of valuable ecosystems for the planet, such as the Amazon. I am sorry to see that while the Commission is announcing a legislative proposal to ensure that products distributed on the European market are not linked to deforestation, it has, on the other hand, pursued negotiations on the trade agreement between the European Union and Mercosur, ignoring the legal obligation to ensure that the agreement does not lead to social, economic and environmental degradation and to the violation of human rights. The Commission must tell us how it intends in practice to reflect the commitments made to protect ecosystems and combat deforestation in trade agreements as well.

name: Adam JARUBAS
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear! Deforestation of the Amazon is a constant point of our concern and debate. We last talked about this last September, wondering how to stop fires in a forest called the lungs of the world and the largest biodiversity centre. As in September, the Commission lists trade agreements with mercosur countries as part of diplomatic measures that can be used to enforce their compliance with the Paris Agreement and to halt amazon deforestation.  Commissioner, you are right to say that stopping the deforestation of the Amazon is in line with the objectives of the European Green Deal and the biodiversity strategy. Let us remember, however, that Europe, if it is to become competitive in implementing the Green Deal, must require similar standards from its trading partners. This is about meeting the climate and sustainability criteria, where we can still use the carbon border adjustment mechanism in the negotiations, alongside the trade agreement. But it is also about meeting the equivalent criteria for animal welfare or food safety that a French, German or Polish farmer must Polish. We must stop deforestation of the Amazon, but this must not be done at the expense of allowing unfair competition in agriculture into Europe and endangering the health of Europeans by marketing foods of unproven quality.

name: Delara BURKHARDT
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. Deep in the north of the Brazilian Amazon lives the indigenous community of the Ituna-Itato. Its territory, the Terra Indégena Ituna-Itata, is under protection. In theory, because in fact, more and more loggers, gold miners, ranchers, soybeans are entering these protected areas, making the area the most damaged indigenous area in Brazil in 2019.  Various laws already enacted or planned by the Bolsonaro government to weaken environmental authorities, facilitate land ownership and amnesty for land grabs leave little to fear. This is a social disaster, but it is also a huge ecological disaster, as the Amazon is destroying one of the most species-rich and important fighters against climate change.  But this is not just a Brazilian affair. Europe also has a responsibility, because 10% of the world's destruction of forests is accounted for by us and our consumption in the European Union, such as soya, palm oil, meat and rubber. Many companies are aware of the problem and are trying to produce more sustainably, but those that continue to cut down forests benefit greatly.  We must not just watch, we must find answers to that. This week, I submitted my draft report for an EU legal framework to curb and reverse global deforestation. I therefore call for companies that want to bring risk-taking assets to the European market soon and financial institutions that support them to pay much more attention to where their products come from and under what circumstances they were produced. This requires binding due diligence. In doing so, we oblige companies that their products have not contributed to the destruction of forests, damage to ecosystems or violation of human rights.  The Ituna-Itata community would also benefit. After all, agricultural products that were grown on the European market from their territory would no longer be allowed to end up on the European market, where rainforest was once and whose agricultural use they did not expressly consent to. The Ituna-Itata cannot rely on their government to give them legal certainty and to assist them in litigation in order to combat land grabs and destruction of nature.  This is the case for many of those affected in countries with weak legal systems or in countries where this is not politically desirable – as in Brazil. That is why they must have access to European courts. Where European companies fail to comply with their due diligence obligations, they must be held liable, because a law without liability is toothless. The Brazilian forest, the Ituna-Itata seem a long way off, but their protection also depends on the products that are on our supermarket shelf. It is up to us to change the rules and make products free of deforestation and human rights violations the norm in Europe. Let's tackle it!

name: Nicolae ŞTEFĂNUȚĂ
text: – Madam President, what distinguishes extraordinary leaders from the weak at such a hard time? What matters is where the priorities are found: the interests of the population in the long term or the interests of a small group in the short term. Leaders whose actions endanger the lives and livelihoods of citizens are often the main sources of conspiracy theories and misinformation and are generally characterized by impulsive decisions, as is this Bolsonaro.  While Brazilians think in fear of tomorrow, having a thousand dead every day because of the Covid-19 crisis, well, Bolsonaro thinks about the group interests of some brazilian businesses, some entrepreneurs, and thinks about it without thinking a little about the interest of the planet, the interest of its citizens and the Amazon. The Brazilian Amazon is on the brink of catastrophe before the fire season has even begun. It follows and we see the planet suffering and burning again. Brazil is taking amazing strides in environmental protection, and this relaxation includes a proposed new law to give title to farmers who illegally occupy indigenous lands.  The numbers don't lie. Last year, 99% of all deforestation in Brazil was illegal, destroying 12,000 square kilometres of natural forest, mostly in the Amazon. Well, in those two minutes that were awarded to me today, no less than six hectares of forest disappeared into the Amazon and 54 hectares of forest disappeared around the world.  I agree with rapporteur Burkhardt that we must also solve this problem at home, because we are part of the problem as well. It's not just in Amazon that this is happening. There are smaller "Amazons" even in Europe. I think we need to lean on them and find a solution now, when it's not too late yet.

name: Marco CAMPOMENOSI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, like all of you, I will be returning to my city this evening. Tomorrow I will meet mayors, entrepreneurs, craftsmen and workers. Some people will ask me: Marco, what did you talk about yesterday in Brussels? Have you talked about how to help our businesses, how to get out of a crisis that will be devastating? No, I'il say we spent the whole morning talking about the Amazon. But did you talk about land grabbing, About China? No, no, we talked about Bolsonaro. Of course, this Parliament spends a lot of time criticising Conservative leaders around the world. We have seen the attitude that this House has had towards Trump in recent years and the attitude he has towards legitimate governments within the European Union itself, I am talking about Poland and Hungary. Today we have seen the references to Bolsonaro as if the problems of the Amazon are born with this government, a government that, among other things, had great difficulties and problems in managing, like all of us, the coronavirus emergency.  The neo-colonial attitude is evident. But how, we take care of it. We Europeans who make trade agreements with Vietnam, which has much lower environmental standards than those of the South American countries. My group, my party, is also critical and strict about the trade agreement with Mercosur, which will fortunately jump at the behest of the South Americans and which makes no sense and which represents a trade model that is outdated. Unfortunately, Commissioner Hogan tells us that no, they will go straight ahead, as if nothing had happened. Well, hypocrisy on our part, which also delegits this Parliament, and it is a pity because I am an opposition, I have to play the villain here, but this attitude penalises everyone and the citizens ask us for different attention and greater thanks.

name: Saskia BRICMONT
text: Madam President, every day Jair Bolsonaro's Brazil deviates further from climate targets: record deforestation in 2020, weakening of environmental protection services and indigenous rights, a bill that endangers protected areas and indigenous peoples. The situation is so serious that the European Parliament is beginning to formally oppose the agreement, that the main British distribution chains are considering boycotting Brazilian products, that NGOs are referring to the European Ombudsman because the Commission has denied the impacts of the Mercosur agreement, before concluding this agreement. But the DG Trade, the DG Trade, insists on minimizing these impacts, even if the Commission and you, Commissioner, repeat that climate targets remain central. I see no sign of the green diplomacy that you are conducting in your own jurisdiction in the current trade policy. In order to implement its own objectives, those of the Green Pact, the Council and the Commission must denounce and demand the withdrawal of the Brazilian bill, they must adopt binding legislation on corporate social responsibility, make trade policy contribute to climate and sustainable development objectives and, finally, recognise that the Mercosur agreement does not meet its social and environmental objectives.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for In May 2019, 739 square kilometers of the amazon rainforest disappeared. That's the equivalent of two football pitches every minute. It is the highest level of devastation in a month of May since the Brazilian Government introduced a satellite monitoring system that measures this particular devastation.  Deforestation of the rainforest in Brazil increased by almost 30 percent between August 2018 and July 2019. A total of 9 762 square kilometres of rainforest were devastated to make way for agricultural land over a 12-month period, an area equivalent to the size of Cyprus. So it is going at a furious pace, how the forest disappears.  In addition, in the first four months of 2020, the cut increased by 55 per cent compared to the same period last year. A total of 1,202 square kilometres of forest were devastated between January and April. It is an area over two and a half times the size of the city of Gothenburg in Sweden. It is the largest devastated area at this time of year since measurements began in August 2015.  This devastation is continuing because of the need for more agricultural land, of being able to grow more palm oil that we consumers in Europe use. We are making a strong contribution to this devastation. The green deal from the EU, where we now want to change, for example, the type of fuel – there will be more environmental fuel for our vehicles – includes a large element of palm oil. Therefore, the need will increase further. The EU wants aircraft to use more environmentally friendly fuels. This will mean an additional increased need for palm oil. We are devastated by the rain forest at an ever-increasing rate because of the decisions we make here, which ordinary people on the street barely understand the background to.  In Sweden, we like to take a beating because our public transport is environmentally friendly, for example, because there we drive with environmental fuel in our buses. It is not environmentally friendly at all. It contributes to the devastation of the rainforest of the Amazon. So while we beat ourselves to the chest and claim that we are environmentally friendly and talented in Sweden who run our public buses on environmentally friendly fuel, the rainforest in the Amazon and the indigenous people are literally evicted from their former places of residence. It's a cynical scenario. Europe urgently needs to review its strategy, because it is completely misguided as it is at the moment. The EU's need for palm oil to produce biofuels will contribute to the even more deforestation of the amazon rainforests, and the rainforests are largely the lungs of the earth. It can't go on. Europe must take greater responsibility.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: – Madam President, what we are witnessing in the Amazon is unfortunately a tragedy announced, it is an attack on the environment and an attack on indigenous communities, which are being decimated first by the occupation of their land and now by the abandonment to which they are being voted in the context of the COVID pandemic—19. In Brazil, we have a president, Jair Bolsonaro, who is a promoter of absolutely criminal activities and actions. We are talking about a country where its president is against its people and indigenous peoples and is against the protection of the Amazon. The Commissioner has said that we are in favour of this protection of both human rights and the Amazon, but he also says that he will continue the negotiation of the European Union-Mercosur Agreement and that in this agreement they will push for these rights to be respected. Let's be very honest and very honest! This agreement has been under negotiation for a long time and there is absolutely no pressure!  In fact, the behavior of the Brazilian authorities is exactly the opposite. That's the more progress the agreement, the more the Amazon is destroyed, the more indigenous communities are attacked.  And in this sense, I would like to appeal to the European Commission: listen to the voices of the Brazilian people, listen to the voices of those who are the lung, the defence of the Amazon lung, which are the indigenous peoples, listen to our voices and end this agreement. We must be on the side of the people and not the multinationals.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Madam President, Commissioner Sinkevičius, the images of the destruction of the Amazon jungle haunt the collective memory in the European Union. They may have left the screens, but the destruction is there, and the Brazilian government is now legally encouraging land grabbing aimed at over-cultivation of soybeans, over-breeding cattle, overexploitation of the forest for rubber production. You know that all these products, to be produced in such large quantities, that means that they are placed on the markets and that is where our strength is. As the European Union, we have the single market and we must use our strength to show the way. It is very important that we check in practice the conditions in our trade relations with the countries in Mercosur. The more we need the trade agreement with the Countries of Mercosur, the more we need the application of the rules of the Paris Agreement. Under no circumstances should we encourage practices that encourage governments to break climate rules and contribute to climate change. The Commission's initiative for a legislative proposal in 2021 actually sets conditions for products that do not meet environmental criteria not to reach the European market, and I would therefore like to thank you, Commissioner. But you know the Amazon is next door - it's here. The whole planet is a neighborhood, as the COVID-19 pandemic unfortunately proved. For this reason, it is necessary to exhaust all pressure on the Brazilian Government and the authorities in the region to take all the necessary measures for this most important 'lung' of the planet. For us and for our children.

name: Nacho SÁNCHEZ AMOR
text: – Madam President, it is a solidified axiom that in these years of populist politicians the lack of democratic quality is always accompanied by an express disregard for environmental quality. We do not know populists who upreed rights and yet are committed to the environment. Authoritarian trends always present this facet of risk to natural resources. Why? Because this that seems so new to us—the Trumps, the Bolsonaros, the Orbán—is actually the latest disguise of ultra-liberal short-term economicism. It is further proof of the dangerous assumption by the conservatives of the far-right agenda and of that idea of an unlimited right to exploitation of natural resources, which each nationalist considers his own because they are within their borders, as if the environment and the consequences of environmental practices could be plotted as political maps. I have heard excellent examples of this environmental nationalism here today.  The Amazon could be regarded, surely without falling into rhetorical abuse, as an environmental resource of all humanity—surely like the Arctic and as few more spaces of that scale—but it is also and above all a resource of its own current inhabitants, many of them indigenous and many of them also those who will have to live in Brazil in the future , and both are being expropriating their rights through deforestation and land occupation by the Government of Bolsonaro. The European Union therefore acts on environmental criteria and also to restore democratic quality, and environmental quality, to these citizens of Brazil's future. And I must tell my Italian colleague that I will be very happy to return to my constituency to say that, when I talk about the Amazon today, I have talked about the wildfires in Extremadura.

name: Pascal DURAND
text: Madam President, I would like to begin my speech by paying tribute to Chico Mendes, who was murdered more than 30 years ago in Brazil for having already defended the Amazon rainforest and syringes. Since his assassination, hundreds of indigenous people and trade unionists have been murdered in Brazil, just four, five even in the last four months.  I would like us not only to denounce And Bolsonaro and the Brazilian government and to identify the culprits. Of course, they have their responsibilities, but let us not forget - as has been said and I want to stress this point - that deforestation, that these crimes against the planet, biodiversity, living, that land grabbing of indigenous peoples, that their own genocide, all this is also our responsibility.  It is to import soybeans to feed our herd and animals in general, it is to import palm oil and fly our planes that this forest is destroyed. That has been said, it is the surface of a football field that is destroyed every second currently in Brazil, half of the world deforestation takes place in the Amazon.  We have to face it. I'm just going to quote a churchman. Four centuries ago, Bossuet said: God laughs at men who deplore the effects and cherish the causes. The time has come to look at our own responsibility, not just to be passive spectators or even accomplices, but to realize that we are the co-authors of these dramas.  As you have said, Commissioner, and we support you on this point, we must immediately change our laws, we must ensure that the duty of vigilance governs our international agreements, we must stop free trade treaties, as they are. Yes, Europe must remain open, but we must make sure to stop and Mercosur and everything that destroys the planet now.

name: Tilly METZ
text: – Madam President, I am shocked to witness the latest surge of deforestation in the Brazilian Amazon. 2020 is on course to become the most destructive year ever for the Amazon. This coincided with the corona pandemic, whose epicentre moved to Brazil. I was dismayed by the statement of the Environment Minister, Ricardo Salles, who wanted to use the fact that the whole world is looking to the pandemic to deregulate and simplify environmental legislation.  So, indigenous people are among the hardest hit, not only because they are losing their land due to illegal logging and land grabbing, but also because of the pandemic — their death rate is twice as high compared with that of the rest of the population.  European companies are also responsible, through their financing of the big landowners and their exploitation of land for food and meat production. This has to end. Consumers need to be alert and we need to stop the dangerous Mercosur deal.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has In one of the recent cabinet meetings, the Bolsonaro government's environment minister suggested that "now that the media is only talking about COVID, we need to use this moment of calm to change all regulations" – regulations that have so far prevented mining and agriculture in protected areas. This mindset of the Bolsonaro government is outrageous! It would be absurd – and yes, that is our responsibility, Mr Durand – if we, as the EU, were now to conclude some kind of trade agreement with this government, which is demonstrably not a word of its promises from the sustainability chapter of the agreement. That is also our responsibility. We must include instruments in our trade policy that prevent crimes against the indigenous population and the environment. Social and environmental standards in international agreements must become binding and enforceable. What would happen in real life if we ratified the Mercosur Agreement? You can then, at most, remind Mr Bolsonaro and the government of the commitments. But he laughs at us. So, commissioner, you do not need to present us with a trade agreement in this House in the first place. We also need a comprehensive supply chain law to address black sheep among European companies that profit from the deforestation of tropical rainforests through imports.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I can only join what my colleagues have said with regard to the situation in Brazil and the issue of deforestation. I can only join those who have criticized the Bolsonaro government on the lack of respect for human rights, the lack of respect for workers' rights, the non-respect of its territory in relation to this deforestation. And I can only join in what Pascal Durand said earlier, which is our co-responsibility as Europeans. Our co-responsibility if we continue to go straight into the wall with trade agreements that have proven today their inability, I say their inability, to enforce the issue of environmental law. So, Commissioner, when you say that the 'sustainable development' chapter, which is compulsory today in trade agreements and Mercosur, but not only Mercosur, in all trade agreements, when you say that this SSD will be able to regulate, well no, Commissioner, this chapter on sustainable development does not regulate anything, it organises discussions but it does not sanction the non-respect of the environment.  So, what we are asking you to do is not marketing, it is not new language, it is coercion, it is sanction and therefore trade agreements, yes, but trade agreements, which are new generation but of a real new generation, which effectively sanction countries, such as Brazil, such as other countries, which do not respect these rights and we also ask that there be a duty for vigilance. and that, when they invest in countries that do not respect human rights, that do not respect environmental rights, victims, wherever they are, have the opportunity to lodge complaints. These complaints must be brought and must be respected, that is the law of humanity. Today, we have indigenous peoples who are exterminated in the Amazon, we must give them the right to file complaints against multinationals that do not respect anything.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: Madam President, the deforestation of the Amazon is the result of a policy as degraded as these large deforested areas which continue to grow every year. The grabbing of wooded areas by individuals can be described as zero degrees of policy. Yes, I say zero degree of politics, because the actors of the degradation of the Amazon rainforest know full well that they can count on the complicity of the current government and its president. The policy breaks with the policy in force between 2004 and 2012-13. At that time, a proactive approach had succeeded in limiting the damage, notably through the strengthening of the Brazilian Environmental Protection Agency and the creation of a fund to support forest conservation projects. The policy also breaks with Brazil's commitments at the Copenhagen climate conference. What can be done about it? With all due sympathy for the tracks explored by the Commission this morning, I doubt their effectiveness. The duty of vigilance of our importing companies on a voluntary basis, fine, but is that sufficient? The same is true of the policy of dialogue or political dialogue. Yes, it must be done out of conscience, but I do not think we will go very far.  Do you think Bolsonaro's going to move? Let us remember that he is part of this kind of men who, at the international level, enjoy important support and who, with the Bible in his hand and the destructive rage in his stomach, are preparing to eliminate one by one the multilateral gains, those gains indispensable to the structuring of our planet threatened in its very existence.  You have understood what I am getting at: simply to the EU-Mercosur trade agreement which, if left unchanged, will be welcomed by Bolsonaro as a bonus to irresponsibility.

name: Caroline ROOSE
text: Madam President, what is happening in the Amazon cannot leave us indifferent. The Amazon rainforest, necessary for the life of indigenous peoples, the lung of humanity, an extraordinary reservoir of biodiversity is being ransacked. It is the prey of a model of industrial agriculture, including intensive soybean cultivation. It is responsible not only for deforestation, but also for pesticide pollution of rivers and rivers, for the destruction of the habitats of many animal species and for land grabbing at the expense of farmers. At the same time, Bolsonaro dismantles environmental protection, promotes illegal logging and violates the rights of indigenous peoples. This is not just a Brazilian problem. When Europe imports GMO soybeans, when it negotiates a free trade agreement with Mercosur, when our banks or companies finance this destruction, Europe is complicit in this ecocide. Climate change and the current crisis show that now is the time to act. Deforestation continues to worsen despite the proliferation of international initiatives. The European Union must show leadership and take strong and concrete action. Tomorrow it'll be too late.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Madam President, since 1970, over 700 000 square kms of the Amazon rainforest has been destroyed. The greed of the agri-business conglomerates and mining corporations on both sides of the Atlantic are the main drivers of this destruction. Climate change mitigation is not a threat to farmers. Neoliberal EU trade deals are the real threat.  Now we have the Mercosur deal, which looks like the European Commission, working in the interests of big business, helping them to find the cheapest raw materials with zero regard for the environment, climate system breakdown or indigenous people.  The Mercosur deal will lead to more deforestation of the Amazon. It will be bad for small farmers in Ireland and all across Europe.  We are forming a new government in Ireland and the Mercosur deal barely got a mention in the programme for government. It says there will be an assessment, which is political speak for doing nothing, despite the fact that Fianna Fáil and the Greens opposed it before now.  Small farmers in Ireland are not just worried about their livelihoods, they are also sick of the hypocrisy of the EU calling out for Member States to reduce agri-emissions, while preparing to import more contaminated, environmentally destructive food and feed from South America.

name: Bernd LANGE
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In fact, deforestation of the Amazon is not a new problem. We have known this for decades now, and so the issue of the trade agreement is not the decisive factor. The crucial thing is that the politics that are being driven there are wrong – and Bolsonaro has undoubtedly re-energized it. That is why we must indeed look at how we can intervene in this area in order to defuse the problem.  It is also quite clear that the problem is also related to the fact that we are importers of raw materials from Brazil. Beef has been mentioned. If this demand side really plays a role, then we are called upon to offer solutions in this demand side as well. The Commission is indeed defensive in this. Two years ago, it launched a communication saying: 'We need additional demand-side regulatory measures to create a level playing field'. These are pious words, but so far nothing has happened. That is why I believe that we really need to start making our demand side fair.  In her report, Mrs Burkhardt made a proposal on a sensible approach to supply chains, which assesses the conditions under which products coming to Europe will ultimately be created. We need to move this forward. And here I expect the Commission to make a proposal to this end, so that we will have legislation in Europe next year.  As far as Brazil is concerned, this is not just Bolsonaro. We have recently seen a survey in Brazil showing that 88% of people in Brazil are also opposed to the deforestation of the jungle. That is why we must support them. Let us also have a dialogue with the regional governments in Brazil, because they are positioning themselves quite differently from Bolsonaro. Support for the people of Brazil is also needed.

name: Stéphane BIJOUX
text: Madam President, this is a message for each and every one of us: I would like to ask ourselves collectively what we are doing here to build the world after. A fairer world, a more united world, a world that puts man and the environment at the centre of every action we take for our survival. What is the meaning of all this if we accept that at the gates of Europe, at the gates of French Guiana, European, there, right next to us, in Brazil, a far-right government coldly lets a criminal plan of mass destruction of the Amazon rainforest run. Criminal against indigenous peoples, criminal against our common heritage of global biodiversity, criminal against future generations. Words are no longer enough. A thousand times we have said this and a thousand times our alerts have crashed on the wall of arrogant cynicism of this far-right president. Because you figure that while we were confined to join forces against coronavirus, well, in Brazil, in May, in a few days, it is the equivalent of 115,000 football fields that were deliberately burned criminally. So not to fight deforestation is to make us complicit in a planned crime against the future of humanity. We dream of a future world but to live, our future needs to breathe and this breath comes from two lungs: the blue lung of the ocean and the green lung of the forest. We dream of a world after but as of today our destinies are linked, no matter where we are on the planet, the time has come to intervene. Fifty years ago, a scientist warned us about the effects of a butterfly beat in Brazil. If we do nothing, soon there will be no more butterflies and there will be no more humans either.

name: Martin HÄUSLING
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which We will never find a vaccine against climate change, that is clear. That is why the issue of climate change and the issue of biodiversity loss will have to come back to the fore when the Corona crisis is over.  But on the subject of Brazil, we are dealing here with a government that is now shamelessly exploiting the crisis to cut even more in the shadow of this crisis. We cannot allow this to happen. And the message is even so brazen and says there is no deforestation at all. All my colleagues have noticed that the Brazilian embassy says that there is no environmental degradation in Brazil at all.  Anyone who makes a deal with this government is complicit in the destruction of the jungle, but also in human rights violations against the indigenous population. We must be clear about this.  We are still the second largest importer of soya. Our agricultural policy produces masses of meat with soya from Brazil and Argentina. Here, too, we must ensure that we finally change our agricultural policy – that is a core of the whole – and do not carry on as before. That is why I am also calling on the Federal Government, in its Presidency of the Council, to remove the mercosur issue from the agenda and instead to put the issues of climate and biodiversity loss at the top.

name: Isabel SANTOS
text: – Madam President, the figures are overwhelming. In 2019, the Amazon lost the equivalent of the area of 2,000 football fields. By 2020, the numbers tend to get worse: more than 1,500 square kilometres have already been deforested.  The action of the Brazilian Government, a country that hosts 60 % of the territory of the Amazon, by promoting the increasing deregulation of the exploitation of this territory and weakening the authorities responsible for its defense, by authorizing the use of land in protected territories and trying to approve mining on indigenous lands, as well as by opening up the possibility of privatization of some 65 million hectares of public land , has been the useful fuse for the exponential increase in the predatory activity of natural resources in the region. Genocide, ethnocide and ecocide were the words used by 600 indigenous leaders earlier this year to describe the environmental and human tragedy resulting from the criminal governance of Jair Bolsonaro. Attacks against environmentalists and indigenous peoples and homicides have increased in a frightening way, spurred by the feeling of total impunity and taking advantage of the lower attention generated by the pandemic. When we're here, is it time we asked what we can do before it's too late? We should strengthen our support for the protection of forests, their peoples and those who defend the forest. Fighting impunity, yes, but more needs to be needed, it is urgently necessary to ban the entry of products associated with deforestation into our supply chains and hold European companies accountable for predatory practices. Yes, it's possible, Commissioner.

name: Thomas WAITZ
text: – Madam President, it’s by nearly 10 000 square kms per year that the rain forest is decreasing, is clear-cut, in the Amazon. The UK alone is responsible for eating up around 500 football fields of beef produced in clear-cut rain forests every single year. In Mato Grosso only, 95% of the clear-cuts for soy production are even illegal under Brazilian law. President Bolsonaro encourages the illegal deforestation. He encourages the human rights violations against the indigenous population.  But we here in the European Union, we are partners in crime. We are responsible for thousands of hectares, square kilometres, of deforestation by importation of beef and soya.  We’re investing billions of euros every single year to tackle climate change and we invest billions of euros to support our European farmers, especially the beef farmers, against this unfair competition on the international markets.  So how can we actually explain that we use the money here to tackle climate change but we encourage the disaster abroad?  This is a Jekyll and Hyde policy! Stop the Mercosur deal and put import bans on soya and beef from Brazil now!

name: Carmen AVRAM
text: – Madam President, during the Covid-19 crisis, phenomena have occurred which surprised and delighted the 21st century European. The air finally became clear and breathable, near the continent's coasts and on the rivers, marine species appeared that modern man had not seen for many decades, and pheasants and deer walked through the streets of some cities.  It was like a demonstration of what we did to nature and a preview of what we could have permanently in 2050 after we've met all the Green Deal conditions. But I also saw the tragic reverse. At the same time, taking advantage of our inattention and in the mad rush for agricultural land, 50% more trees have been cut down in the Amazon forest than in the same period last year, and the trend of illegal deforestation remains upward. By putting our perspective and the reality of others face to face, I think the time has come to temper our optimism about the goodwill and will of some states that we want partners to act as Europe acts, and we need to move to imposing tougher conditions in negotiations and imports.  As shadow rapporteur on the new forest strategy, I know what efforts will be made by our farmers and forest owners to comply with all the conditions and contribute to the Green Deal, but if we do not impose the exact same conditions and rigors on others, not only will we not stop the Amazonian malaxor, but we will encourage unfair competition from which we will lose. Green Deal is ours, but it can't just be for us.

name: Pär HOLMGREN
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The Amazon is the lungs of the world, it is sometimes said, but actually the rain forest works contrary to our lungs. The rainforest binds carbon and releases oxygen, and there are huge amounts of carbon. The Amazon rainforest is also one of the most sensitive parts of the entire Earth's climate system.  I'm a meteorologist. We meteorologists know the risks everyone in this room, and of course everyone outside too, is exposed to if the Amazon rainforests continue to disappear. The importance of the Amazon for the earth's climate is not something we can debate in this House. It's a scientific fact.  So to all of you in this Chamber who nevertheless think that economic considerations should take precedence over stopping the devastation, I wonder: Do you think you can breathe from an annual report? Do you think you can grow your food on the stock exchange? Do you literally think you can eat money? If not, then act in this House, because we must all begin to live within the limits of the planet.

name: Virginijus Sinkevičius
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, today’s debate has sent a clear message from the Parliament that tackling deforestation in the Amazon is a priority across almost all the political spectrum. It has also shown a clear understanding that the multi—faceted challenges that affect the Amazon basin, its immense natural resources and its populations need to be tackled in a holistic manner and in the context of sustainable development objective working in partnership with the countries in the region. You, Ms McGuinness, have rightly said that we need to look at the complexity of our supply chain. This is very true and challenging, but I can reassure you that this is exactly what we are doing. I work very closely with all my colleagues concerned to bring together environmental, agricultural, trade, health and climate aspects of deforestation. Let me reassure you that the Commission is not only providing significant technical and financial assistance to countries in the region to tackle these challenges, and that we talk to and listen carefully to the indigenous people who are directly impacted and at risk, as you, Ms Burkhardt and also Ms Matias, have mentioned. We are also working on domestic policies to reduce the EU’s own footprint on forests abroad, in addition, in close cooperation with the European External Action Service and the diplomatic services of EU Member States. We are using all available diplomatic channels to engage on this important topic. The Commission is already taking action to support efforts across the globe to tackle the root causes of deforestation and to protect the rights of indigenous people and local communities, which are threatened by land grabbing and deforestation. In this respect I look forward to the outcome of your future deliberations on the legislative initiative report by Ms Burkhardt, on the legal framework to halt and reverse EU—driven global deforestation after years of damages that cannot be repaired. And ahead of landmark international meetings, such as COP26 in Glasgow and the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) COP15 in Kunming, it’s clear that we are at a critical junction to succeed. We need to scale up efforts towards preserving critical ecosystems such as forests, not only as a solution to climate change and biodiversity challenge, but also achieve sustainability and resilience. In reply to many of you who mentioned the government in Brazil, we call on national authorities, including Brazilian authorities, to take decisive action to address deforestation and to cooperate regionally and internationally to this end. We stand ready to provide technical assistance in order to ensure that deforestation decreases rapidly, substantially and permanently should there be a clear willingness for cooperation on this issue. Let me agree also with Mr Ştefănuță, who reminded us that the problem of deforestation does not only exist abroad but also close to us in Europe. I can only say to you that I am following closely developments in Europe and I am determined to take strong action also at home. Since many of you have mentioned free trade agreements, let me recall that all our modern free trade agreements contain ambitious, even if imperfect, provisions to promote trade and sustainable development. The fact that we conclude negotiations for an association agreement with the Mercosur countries does not mean that we agree with all the policies of those governments in all areas, clearly not. But it is a way of having reciprocal binding commitments to the Paris Agreement as foreseen by the EU—Mercosur agreement. It is a way of having dialogue and working with Brazil and the other partners in the region to push and encourage each other to live up to the commitments we have made together in the Paris Agreement and to work together on the environmental issues. Mercosur countries, including Brazil, have included commitments on deforestation in their Paris Agreement pledges reinforced by private sector initiatives, such as that of Brazilian meatpackers not to source meat from farms in recently deforested areas and the Amazon soya moratorium, an independent Brazilian multi stakeholder initiative.  Honourable Members, to conclude, yes, there is still a lot of work to do and we will continue our work on the legislative proposal that we will present next year and I look forward to working closely with you on this important issue.

name: Christine ANDERSON
text: Writing. – Land grabs and deforestation, two offences against Mother Nature, perpetrated by a small number of profit-oriented people who do not care about the consequences of their actions for the rest of society. They cut down trees, destroy habitats for a variety of animals and condense formerly fertile soils so sustainably that only a barren steppe remains instead of a previously magnificent green landscape. With such an overexploitation of Mother Nature, man, only for short-term financial success, takes the space for his own life piece by piece and thus literally saws at the branch on which he sits.  Members of this House are turning their attention to the Amazon. As in many other debates, however, this so-called Parliament is permanently overestimating its competence, because as long as the Amazon is not part of the EU, we should rather look at our Member States, where nothing else happens regularly and land grabs and deforestation are undertaken to promote an alleged energy transition that is not one.

name: Alexander BERNHUBER
text: Writing. – It is no secret that Brazil is illegally cutting down the Amazon rainforest in favour of agricultural factories. Since the beginning of 2020, more than 2 000 square kilometres of forest have been cleared. That's 34% more than last year and a shameful world record! If an increase in beef exports is seen, Brazil will create more land for cattle breeding. It is therefore clear that deforestation is linked to the Mercosur trade agreement. Why the Commission and many Member States indirectly support this deal, and hence illegal grub-up, is a mystery to me. This runs counter to the values and image of the EU, especially now that the Green Deal has become the european Union's label and the Commission has set the ambitious goal of making Europe the first climate-neutral continent. As a young person, one of my most important concerns is to leave the earth as a good habitat for all. If grubbing-up continues in this way, it will harm the environment and the climate in the long term. If the slash-and-burn continues, we must take joint action against it. We must not watch the rainforest burn in favour of Mercosur products.

name: César LUENA
text: in writing. – The situation in Brazil regarding the management of the Amazon rainforest and the COVID-19 pandemic is very alarming. The coronavirus pandemic is endangering indigenous communities and is being used as a tool to distract the media and allow legislation to dilute forest environmental protection and environmental controls without any questions.  The EU must react firmly by legislating for deforestation-free chains. We need to fight for deforestation-free chains in the EU, implementing a system of 'deforestation-free import' certificates or efficient verification of 'deforestation-free export' certificates issued by exporting countries.  In turn, the forthcoming Mercosur Agreement must have a binding sustainable development chapter to enable the EU to act in the face of brazil's non-compliance and abuse. Proposals for laws such as land grabbing must have a strong response from the international community.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the second round of voting. The voting round is open from 1.45 p.m. to 3 p.m. The same voting procedure will apply as in the previous voting rounds. I declare the second round of voting open. You can vote until 3 p.m.  The results of the second round of voting will be announced at 5.30 p.m. (The sitting was suspended at 1.35 p.m.)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the third round of voting. The voting round is now open until 7 p.m. The same voting procedure will apply as in the previous voting rounds. I declare the third round of voting open. You can vote until 7 p.m. The results of the third round of voting will be announced from this location at 9.30 p.m. (The sitting was suspended at 5.35 p.m.)

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: I declare the Sitting of the European Parliament interrupted.
